page.title: Tēvita ʻUnga/en
page.text:
Tēvita ʻUnga was the oldest son of Tāufaʻāhau, king Siaosi Tupou, I but not the crownprince as he was considered illegitimate. When his father by 1834 had usurped enough power to take any wife he wanted, he took [[Sālote Lupepauʻu]], a Tuʻi Tonga Fefine, the highest ranking woman around. And he declared all previous wives divorced and their offspring illegitimate. However when the last crownprince [[Vuna Takitakimālohi]] had died, his father had not much choice and made Tēvita and his son, [[Uelingatoni Ngū]] the appointed successors in the constitution.
When Tupou I had conquered Tongatapu and moved his residence to there, Tēvita remained behind in Vavaʻu as a governor. Only when his father was unpleasantly surprised that establishing a constitution, in 1875, was not enough to get the esteem of the foreign powers, but that he also had to appoint ministers, Tēvita became the first prime minister, but soon, 1879, left his job in a mess behind and went to New Zealand for medical treatmnet. There he died.
Meanwhile his son, Uelingatoni Ngū (Wellington Gu) had taken over as acting governor of Vavaʻu. In the Poʻopoʻoi newspaper of September 1876 it is described he had to pay a fine of 6 dollars and one shilling because his dog bit a man called Tevi.
Julius Brenchley visited Vavaʻu for 5 days in July 1865 and met the governor, David Uga (as his name was written at that time). He described him as: tall, imposing-looking in spite of the loss of an eye … minus two fingers, cut off as a tribute to some deceased relatives.
*J.L. Brenchley: Jottings during the cruise of H.M.S. Curacoa among the South sea islands in 1865: London 1873 *Koe Boobooi, editor Shirley W. Baker: vol II (March 1875 – November 1877) {{Foki||Tēvita ʻUnga}}

page.title: Mei/en
page.text: The breadfruit ''(mei)'' is an important foodsource for Tonga. The breadfruit tree ''(fu'u mei)'' is also an important shader. {{Foki||mei}}

page.title: Fakamatala/en
page.text:
The '''information''' box should appear with every uploaded image. '''Images without may be deleted without further ado.'''
The following data is to be provided (examples in green): *Fakamahino (description):<font color="#008800"> What is it? A short but powerful.</font> *Tupunga (source):<font color="#008800"> Where you got it from? Own artwork, scan, photo?</font> *ʻAho (date):<font color="#008800"> When made? The date either of this picture or of the original. Typing in 5 tildes (<nowiki>~~~~~</nowiki>) automatically makes it now.</font> *Faʻufaitā (photographer, artist):<font color="#008800"> Who made it? If it is you then typing in 3 tildes (<nowiki>~~~</nowiki>) automatically makes it yours.</font> *Fakangofua (license):<font color="#008800"> Any license, as long as it is true and valid in the wikipedia spirit.</font> {{Foki|s|Fakamatala}}

page.title: Tāufaʻāhau Tupou IV/en
page.text:
*Puha TUPUʻANGA, tangata, fefine : genealogy box, man, woman *mātuʻa, ʻeiki/tamai & fehuhu/faʻē : parents, father & mother *tokoua : brothers and sisters (usually including half brothers/sister and adopted, but not those born out of wedlock) *ʻohoana, ʻaho mali, fānau : spouse, wedding date, children
He was baptised as: '''Siaosi Tāufaʻāhau Tupoulahi'''. In his youth he was called: '''Tāufaʻāhau'''. When he came on age he got the chiefly title for crownprinces: '''Tupoutoʻa''' and was named as such. After the death of his father he also got the title '''Tungī''' and was named Tuboutoa-Tugi (in old ortography) and as such known being the prime minister. And as king he was known as '''Tāufaʻāhau Tupou IV''', and ex officio he also was then the '''Tuʻi Kanokupolu'''. {{Foki||Tāufaʻāhau Tupou IV}}

page.title: Kāinga ofi/en
page.text: *Puha TUPUʻANGA : genealogy box, with nam, gender, birthdate, deathdate **tangata : man **fefine : woman **ʻotua : god *mātuʻa : parents **tamai : father (''ʻeiki'' for aristocracy) **faʻē : mother (''fehuhu'' for aristocracy) *tokoua : brothers and sisters (usually including half brothers/sister and adopted, but not those born out of wedlock) *ʻohoana : spouse **ʻaho mali : wedding date (''taʻane'' for royalty) **fānau : children {{Foki|s|Kāinga ofi}}

page.title: Sālote Tupou III/en
Houʻeiki/en
page.text: This is a succession box for the Tongan nobility. The title and the holder in the middle, the predecessor to the left, the successor to the right, and the nomination date (fakanofo) with the ceremonial installation or crowning date (pongipongi) (if known) and the retirement date (mālōlō) to the bottom. {{Foki|f|Houʻeiki}}

page.title: Fale fakataha/en
page.text:
[[File:Wikipedia-logo-to.png|right]] Let us talk about this ''Wiki''. Do not be shy, add your opinion on this page (registered users only). But rubbish, scoldings and so on will be removed.
==Only Tongan language== But if there is an article that may be interesting for foreigners, add an English translation, even if only it is an abstract. See [[Contents/en|Help:Contents]] how to do it.
==Proper spelling== Use proper spelling with full glottal stop, macrons and accents as in the Churchward dictionary. This encyclopedia has to set an example to us all. Yes, you can help too by editing.
Do not use an old browser, like ''MS Internet explorer''. It is known not able to show the glottal stop. There are plenty new browsers, many even for free. Try ''Firefox''.
==Discussions== A list of various discussions, currently or in the past. *[[Wikipedia talk:Mumui Tupouʻila Mapatongiamanu]]
==Translations== There are a lot of articles on the English and other ''Wikipedia'' which needs translations. Volunteers please.
===[[betawiki:|Betawiki]]=== Also a request from Betawiki: :If you for example log in to the English Wikipedia, and change your user interface language to Tongan, you will not be able to use the translations made here. With other words, there are no translations for Tongan in the software. :But there is [[betawiki:|Betawiki]] where you can easily translate into any language. We have imported the translations made here to Betawiki so they will be usable on every wiki with this software, including all Wikipedia's. If you are going to do more translations, I want to invite you to do that on Betawiki, so those new translations are also on every wiki available. :Another advantage is that you can translate on Betawiki the namespaces (Talk, User, ...) and the special page names (Special:Recentchanges, Special:Userlogin, ...). {{Foki||Wikipedia:Fale fakataha}}
==Fundraising 2010: Beat Jimmy Challenge==
The Fundraising Committee is issuing all interested community members a challenge: [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Fundraising_2010 we want you to beat Jimmy]. The appeal from Jimmy Wales and the corresponding banner have been tested head-to-head with other successful banners, and the results are clear: it's our best performing message... by a lot. This year we have a lofty fundraising goal; we need all of our banners to bring in donations like the Jimmy Appeal, but no one wants to keep the Jimmy banner up for two months. We want to run donor quotes, and other wonderful ideas, but we have to have banners that work as well as or better than the Jimmy appeal.
We've just released the highlights from a [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Fundraising_2010#Focus_Group donor focus group], and the results of our [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:FR_Donor_survey_report.pdf donor survey]. With one month to the launch of the fundraiser, the messages we test must be driven by data from our tests and surveys - we can no longer rely on instinct alone.
We've redesigned our fundraising meta pages with the Jimmy challenge; check out the survey results and propose/discuss banners that reflect these findings. Add the banners you think will 'beat Jimmy' [http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Fundraising_2010/Messages/BeatJimmy here] to be tested '''Tuesday October 12''' against Jimmy. -[[User:Dgultekin|Dgultekin]] 00:01, 7 ʻOkatopa 2010 (UTC)

page.title: Edward Tuivanuavou Tugi Cakobau
page.text: {{Kāinga ofi |faʻahinga=houʻeiki |hokohoko=Cakobau, ETT |maama= tangata |tamai= [[Siaosi Tupou II]] |faʻē= [[Litia Cakobau]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= 21 Tisema 1908 |ʻaho pekia= 26 Sune 1973 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= ? |fānau1= {{tokoua|(Ratu) Viliame Dreunimisimisi|(Ratu) Epeli Nailatikau|-|(Ratu) Tuʻuakitau Cokanauto|||||}} |}}Ko e '''ratu''' ia (ko e ʻeiki faka-Fisi). ʻOku ui ko '''Tungīfisi''' ʻi heʻene meʻa ki Tonga ʻi 1934, pe hono hingoa fakaheliaki ko e '''langakali ʻo Peka''' (langakali ʻo Beqa, ʻi Fisi).

page.text: {{Houʻeiki|fakanofo= Fielakepa |hokohoko=Aleamotuʻa, ST |ʻaho fakanofo= 17 Nōvema 1964 |ʻaho pongipongi= |ʻaho fakamālōlō=19 ʻEpeleli 1997 |ki muʻa=[[Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa (punake)|Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa]] |hoko=[[Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa]] |}} Ko hono hingoa nonou naʻe: Fielakepa (Longolongo). {{Kāinga ofi |faʻahinga=houʻeiki |hokohoko=Aleamotuʻa, PLʻ |maama=tangata |tamai=[[Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa (punake)|Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa]] |faʻē= Sālote Halaevalu Kalasini Maeakafa |ʻaho fanauʻi=1938 |ʻaho pekia=19 ʻEpeleli 1997 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|Kaifonuaʻamanu Tupouniua (Aleamotuʻa)|Mele Moala Vī (Aleamotuʻa)|Siaosi Maeakafa Aleamotuʻa|Siaosi Takalafatu Aleamotuʻa|Siaosi Niumeitolu Aleamotuʻa||||||}} |ʻohoana1= Mele Tunakaimanu Lilian Aleamotuʻa |ʻaho1= |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Kaimana Hauoli ʻo Kuini Tukuʻaho (Aleamotuʻa)|Kaimana Hauoli ʻo Kuini]]|[[Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa|Siosaia Tupou]]|Temaleti Manakovi Momoho Pahulu (Aleamotuʻa)|[[Mosese Tanaki Taulupe ki Folaha Aleamotuʻa|Mosese Taulupe]]|Sālote Halaevalu Kalasini Aleamotuʻa|[[Tupou Tongapoʻuli Aleamotuʻa|Tupou Tongapoʻuli]]|||}} |}}*http://www.tongatapu.net.to/tonga/news/briefs/ss970424.htm

page.title: Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa
page.link: Mosese Tanaki Taulupe ki Folaha Aleamotuʻa
Malia ʻi Lutu Losaline Tae Falaula Aleamotuʻa (Langi)
page.text:
{{Houʻeiki|fakanofo= Fielakepa |hokohoko=Aleamotuʻa, ST |ʻaho fakanofo= 19 ʻEpeleli 1997 |ʻaho pongipongi= |ʻaho fakamālōlō= 10 Fēpueli 2013 |ki muʻa=[[Paula Longolongoʻatumai ʻAtunaisa Aleamotuʻa]] |hoko=[[Tupou Tongapoʻuli Aleamotuʻa]] |}} Ko e pāloni ia mei he 2008.
{{Kāinga ofi |faʻahinga=houʻeiki |hokohoko=Aleamotuʻa, ST |maama=tangata |tamai= [[Paula Longolongoʻatumai ʻAtunaisa Aleamotuʻa]] |faʻē= Mele Tunakaimanu Aleamotuʻa |ʻaho fanauʻi=1961 |ʻaho pekia= 10 Fēpueli 2013 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Kaimana Hauoli ʻo Kuini Tukuʻaho (Aleamotuʻa)]]||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| ||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|Temaleti Manakovi Pahulu (Aleamotuʻa)|[[Mosese Tanaki Taulupe ki Folaha Aleamotuʻa]]|Sālote Halaevalu Kalasini Aleamotuʻa|[[Tupou Tongapoʻuli Aleamotuʻa]]|||||}} |ʻohoana1=[[Malia ʻi Lutu Losaline Tae Falaula Aleamotuʻa (Langi)]] |ʻaho1= 8 Sānuali 2010 |fānau1= {{tokoua|ʻikai, mavae Mē 2011||||||||}} |}}*http://tonga-broadcasting.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2209&Itemid=57 *http://www.taimionline.com/articles/3817 *http://matangitonga.to/2013/02/11/baron-fielakepa-passes-away-auckland

page.title: Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa (punake)
page.category: Hiva fakatonga|Aleamotuʻa ST
page.text:
{{Houʻeiki|fakanofo= Fielakepa |hingoa= Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa |hokohoko= Aleamotuʻa, ST (lahi) |ʻaho fakanofo= |ʻaho fakamālōlō= 13 Nōvema 1963 |ki muʻa= [[Siaosi Niumeitolu Aleamotuʻa]] |hoko= [[Paula Longolongoʻatumai ʻAtunaisa Aleamotuʻa]] |}} Ko hono hingoa nonou naʻe: Fielakepa (Siosaia), tamai ʻo Longolongo, ko e ʻuhinga ʻoku tatau ia mo hono mokopuna. {{Kāinga ofi |faʻahinga=houʻeiki |hingoa= Siosaia Tupou Aleamotuʻa |hokohoko= Aleamotuʻa, ST (lahi) |maama=tangata |tamai= [[Tongaliuaki Aleamotuʻa]] |faʻē= |ʻaho fanauʻi=24 Sune 1912 |ʻaho pekia=13 Nōvema 1963 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Siaosi Niumeitolu Aleamotuʻa]]||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| ||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|Vasa|Luʻisa Tupou Kafaloto|||||||}} |ʻohoana1=? |ʻaho1= |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Paula Longolongoʻatumai ʻAtunaisa Aleamotuʻa|Paula Longolongoʻatumai ʻAtunaisa]]|Kaifonuaʻamanu Tupouniua (Aleamotuʻa)|Mele Moala Vī (Aleamotuʻa)|Siaosi Maeakafa|Siaosi Takalafatu|Siaosi Niumeitolu||||}} |}} Ko e ʻuhinga ''punake'' ʻi he kupú ni, naʻe fatu ia ʻa e ngaahi fasi ʻiloa, fakatātā: Leihuni, ~1960.
==Leihuni ʻo Pilolevu== Leihuni ʻo [[Sālote Mafileʻo Pilolevu Tuita (Tukuʻaho)|Pilolevu]] leipua ʻo [[Tupou VI|ʻAhoʻeitu]] [[Fatafehi ʻAlaivahamamaʻo Tukuʻaho|ʻAlai]] mo hono papai kukuvalu ka nau sikeiti ʻi loto [[Haveluloto|Havelu]] ko e ʻau ʻatā ʻa e ʻikai hano tatau.
Ipulahi fungani ho sisi ko e fofonga naʻe tui mei he [[Alafolau-heavula]] satelaite ʻo e [[Haveluloto|Painituʻuua]] ʻoku vilo mo meleketu ʻi he ngalu ʻea ko e ʻau ʻatā foʻi [[alamea]] [[Haveluloto|Pikipeavela]].
ʻOfa loto he [[tavake|ekiaki]] ʻoku ngaholo fuifui lupe ʻo e [[Sia-ko-Veiongo]] ʻoku nau siu ʻi [[:Category:Kauhalaʻuta|ʻUta]] pea mo [[:Category:Kauhalalalo|Lalo]] ʻo āutō he ngatae epu Maʻopoʻopo haʻu ta ʻeva hala koula ʻo Vahamamaʻo.
==Tataku== *Langi tauʻolunga & hiva kakala; Nukuʻalofa 2000; ISBN 978-982-98007-1-8 [[Category:Hiva fakatonga|Aleamotuʻa ST]]

page.title: Nganatatafu
Mataukipā
Sinaitakalaʻilangileka
Talakaifaiki/en
page.text: The Sāmoan warriors were victorious in their independence war against Tonga. It was this Tuʻi Tonga they defeated. During his fleeing away from the final battleground at Tualatala in Sāmoa, Talakaifaiki (Talaʻifeiʻi in Sāmoan) is reported to have said from aboard his canoe: Brave warriors, bravely fought whenever I shall come back it shall be a friendly return and not a tide of war! {{Foki||Talakaifaiki}}

page.title: Havea I/en
page.text: Havea was murdered while he was bathing in the Tolopona (near ʻAlakifonua). Het died a terrible death, he was cut in two. {{Foki||Havea I}}

page.title: Tatafuʻeikimeimuʻa/en
page.text: There is a story where he is only called Tatafu-mei-Muʻa (Tatafu from Muʻa). Unless that was a different person. But in that story he and his younger brother went to Sāmoa to woo a beautiful lady named Hina. {{Foki||Tatafuʻeikimeimuʻa}}

page.title: Nganatatafu/en
page.text: Nganatatafu lived in [[Haʻano]], Haʻapai, and accompanied his brother on a quest for Hina, a beautiful lady from Sāmoa. She gave him the first bonito to enter Tongan waters. It is said that the chiefly line of Tuʻihaʻangana started from him. {{Foki||Nganatatafu}}

page.title: Havea II/en
page.text: This Havea was also murdered, shot with an arrow in the head by Tuluvota from Fiji. Otherwise we might think that Havea I and II were the same person, and that time has corrupted their history. {{Foki||Havea II}}

page.title: Takalaua/en
Moʻungāmotuʻa/en
page.text: Moʻungāmotuʻa sent his oldest son, Tāufatofua, away to be a governor of [[Tofua]]. He, the other sons, grandsons, Moʻungāmotuʻa himself, each of them became an ancestor of one of the families still belonging nowadays to the [[:Category:Haʻa Takalaua|Takalaua clan]]. {{Foki||Moʻungāmotuʻa}}

page.title: Kauʻulufonua (fekai)/en
Vakafuhu/en
Puipuifatu/en
page.text: Puipuifatu lived in Sāmoa where he became a [[Tuʻi Manuʻa]], and he also was the ancestor of the [[:Category:Tuʻiʻāfitu|Tuʻiʻāfitu]]. He tried to invade Tonga to restore his power, but was defeated in Vavaʻu. {{Foki||Puipuifatu}}

page.title: Tapuʻosi/en
page.text: Tapuʻosi was the Tuʻi Tonga who returned from exile in Sāmoa. Not as reigning king, but rather as a priestly god, which elevated status would remain so for the rest of the dynasty. This happened when either Siulangapō or Vakalahimoheʻuli was the Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua. {{Foki||Tapuʻosi}}

page.title: ʻEuakafa
page.text:
[[Image:ʻEuakafa (1).gif|right|350px|thumb|ʻEuakafa (motu)]] [[Image:ʻEuakafa.jpg|left|400px|thumb|Ko e motu ʻi heʻene ʻasi mei [[Taunga]]]] Ko '''ʻEuakafa''' ko e kiʻi motu ia ʻi he ʻotu motu tonga ʻo [[:category:Vavaʻu|Vavaʻu]]. ʻOku ʻikai nofo ha tokotaha, ka ʻoku ʻi ai ha ngaahi ʻapi ngoue ʻo e kakai mei he ngaahi motu kāungaʻapi. ʻI ʻolunga ʻo e motu ʻoku toe ʻa e faʻitoka ʻo [[Talafaiva]], ko e pele ʻo e Tuʻi Tonga [[ʻUluakimata I|Teleʻa]].
Ko e tofiʻa ʻo e puleʻanga ʻo Tonga. {{feituʻu Tonga|18°756|174°037}} {{potuʻi}} [[category:Vavaʻu]]

page.title: Nōpele/en
Tuʻi Tonga Fefine/en
page.text:
In the beginning of the 17th century the current Tongan ranking system became well established. This was probably due to the invasion of [[ʻUluakimata I]] with his 500 [[ʻUvea]]n warriors to claim the title of the [[:category:Tuʻi Tonga|Tuʻi Tonga]] a century or so before. It was a long time of social changes, but Tongan culture changed from something completely different then, to the structure it still has nowadays.
In the new system the rank of the sisters of the Tuʻi Tonga was higher than of the king himself, especially the rank of his his oldest sister. She became known as the '''Tuʻi Tonga Fefine''' (female Tonga king; but she was not his wife). (These 'real' Tuʻi Tonga Fefine are different from the occasional named Tuʻi Tonga Fefine during earlier generations.) [[Sinaitakalaʻilangileka]] was the first Tuʻi Tonga Fefine.
Evidentlty the Tuʻi Tonga Fefine was not really a dynasty with a daughter succeeding on her mother's death. Their existence followed the Tuʻi Tonga, so there could be one, or none, or perhaps two Tuʻi Tonga Fefine at any particular time.
A Tuʻi Tonga Fefine had to marry a foreigner, because her children would be higher ranking than the Tuʻi Tonga himself. But as non-Tongans these children would not eligible to compete for Tongan kingship, whatever high the rank, leaving teh Tuʻi Tonga alone. Or so was the official belief and explanation. With them started the [[:category:Haʻa Falefisi|Fale Fisi]], of which the [[:category:Tuʻilakepa|Tuʻilakepa]] and the [[:category:Tuʻihaʻateiho|Tuʻihaʻateiho]] were the leading lineages, and also started the institution of the [[:category:Tamahā|Tamahā]], the oldest daughter of the Tuʻi Tonga Fefine. *D.V. Burley; Sacred child and sacred place; Polynesian paradox, USP 2005; ISBN 982-02-0371-6 *http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m2375/is_n2_v32/ai_20554487/pg_7 {{Foki|f|Tuʻi Tonga Fefine}}

page.title: Sinaitakalaʻilangileka/en
Tamahā/en
Haʻa Falefisi/en
page.text: The Fale Fisi (the dynasty of Fiji) started when [[Sinaitakalaʻilangileka]], the first [[:Category:Tuʻi Tonga Fefine|Tuʻi Tonga Fefine]] had to marry a foreigner, as she was too high ranked for any Tongan. That was Tapuʻosi, a Fijian, the ''Tui Lakeba''. {{Foki|f|Haʻa Falefisi}}

page.title: Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua/en
page.text: The Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua family (kāinga) is the head of the Takalaua clan (haʻa). The Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua is one of the three major royal lines of modern Tonga. The first ruler was Moʻungāmotuʻa. Originally it was the Kauhalalalo itself, then it became part of it, and finally it was brushed aside by the Tuʻi Kanokupolu into the Kauhalaʻuta. {{Foki|f|Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua}}

page.title: Moʻungaʻotonga/en
Ngata/en
Kaloafūtonga/en
Kaloafūtonga
Māʻitaki
Māʻitaki/en
page.text:
The '''māʻitaki''' (a word related to the Sāmoan ''tamataʻi'' (lady)) was a daughter of the [[:category:Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua|Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua]] who married with the [[:category:Tuʻi Tonga|Tuʻi Tonga]] to become his principal wife and the mother of his heir. As personal rank in Tonga comes from the mother, this elevated the status of the future Tuʻi Tongas, and increased the power of the Tuʻi Haʻatakalauas, becuase of the [[fahu]] system. It was thus advantageous to both [[kāinga]].
The first māʻitaki was [[Kaloafūtonga]] around 1600, the last [[Longomāʻitaki]] around 1700.
The system lasted only for 4 generations, as by then the power of the Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua had been eclipsed by the [[:category:Tuʻi Kanokupolu|Tuʻi Kanokupolu]], and the Tuʻi Tonga started to take his principal wife from the latter kāinga. They were called '''moheofo''' (meaning: to wake up (a lord)). Originally, however, the term was to indicate a young woman sleeping with a visiting chief, as was normal in former times.
The first moheofo was [[Tongotea]] around 1700. It was a habit that they were brought at night to their new husbands. (Tongotea's older sister [[Halaevalu]] also married a Tuʻi Tonga, but this seems to have been more a try out, and she did not become mother of the next king).
As consequence nowadays the word māʻitaki has degenerated into a general term for concubine, while moheofo is a reference to the royal family. Quite opposite to their original meanings.
==References== *C.M. Churchward, Tongan dictionary, Tonga 1959 *I.C. Campbell, Island kingdom, Canterbury university press, 1992, 2001 {{Foki||Māʻitaki}}

page.title: Tuʻutangahunuhunu
Tuʻutangahunuhunu/en
page.text: Although Tuʻutanga married a Tuʻi Tonga, it is not sure it was ʻUluakimata or an earlier or later king. In any case most likely she was not a principal wife but merely one of the concubines. Paku would grow up to become the fisherman of the Tuʻi Tonga, and his offspring is the [[:Category:Fakafānua|Fakafānua]] chiefly line. {{Foki||Tuʻutangahunuhunu}}

Viliami Kalaniuvalu
page.text:
{{Houʻeiki|fakanofo= Kalaniuvalu |ʻaho fakanofo= 1865 |ʻaho fakamālōlō= 1903 |ki muʻa= (ʻuluaki ia) |hoko= [[Semisi Fonua Kalaniuvalu]] |}}
{{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=houʻeiki |maama= tangata |tamai= [[Sanualio Laufilitonga]] |faʻē= [[Luseane Halaevalu Mataʻaho]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= ~1828 |ʻaho pekia= 1903 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Manumataongo]]||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| ||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Lavinia Veiongo (māhanga)]]|[[Hepisipa]]|[[Fakauakimanuka]]|Fatafehi Fangaʻafā|||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[ʻUngatea Kioa]] |fānau1= {{tokoua|||[[Sioeli Pangia]]|[[Leafāʻitulangi]]|||||}} |ʻohoana2= Taupeavai |fānau2= {{tokoua|||Siaosi Fatafehi||||||}} |}}*http://web.archive.org/web/20030311031745/http://www.uq.net.au/~zzhsoszy/states/tonga/tuitonga.html Ko e māhanga ia mo hono tuofefine, Lavinia Veiongo. Ko hono hingoa lōloa: '''Viliami Fatafehiʻolapaha Kalaniuvalu'''.
Naʻe tuku ʻa e hingoa ʻo e [[:category:Tuʻi Tonga|Tuʻi Tonga]] ʻe [[Siaosi Tupou I]] ʻi 1865 ʻosi ʻa e hala ʻo [[Sanualio Laufilitonga]]. Kae naʻe fokotuʻu maʻa hono foha, ko Viliami, ʻa e huafa fakanofo foʻou, ko e [[:category:Kalaniuvalu|Kalaniuvalu]]. Naʻe hoko ia ki he hingoa fakanōpele ʻi 1875.
ʻOsi ʻene pekia naʻe ʻoatu ʻa e ngaahi tofiʻa ki hono foha, Sioeli, kae ʻikai ʻe fakanofo ia ʻi he huafa.

page.text: {{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=houʻeiki |hingoa=Sālote Mafileʻo Pilolevu |maama= fefine |tamai= [[Siaosi Tupou I]] |faʻē= [[Fīnau Kaunanga]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= 1824 |ʻaho pekia= 18 Sēpitema 1891 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Tēvita ʻUnga]]|[[ʻIsileli Tupou]]|[[Tuʻuakitau]]|[[Vuna Takitakimālohi]]|||||}} |ʻohoana1=[[Filiaipulotu]] |ʻaho1= 1839 |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Siaosi Fatafehi Toutaitokotaha]]||||||||}} |}}[[File:Semi-formal outdoor portrait in front of the Tongan palace, 1884.jpg|center|800px|thumb|ʻI muʻa ʻo pālasi, 1884, ko Sālote ʻi toʻohema]]

page.title: Shirley Waldemar Baker/en
Siosāteki Tonga Veikune/en
page.text:
Sāteki, as he was normally known, had been an old friend of [[Shirley Waldemar Baker]], who had been hated by the chiefs and traders. The fact that Sāteki was no chief himself, only added to the misgivings of the chiefs. But for a Tongan, of his time, he showed a remarkable dexterity in administration and quickly undid the mess from his predecessor. Unfortunately he had the raise taxes again and again and again to keep up with the spending thrift of the king. By 1897 it was no longer possible to raise taxes any higher, and he had to get loans from traders, essentially selling Tonga to foreign business men. The Hutter brothers of Auckland in particular.
The king, firstly having a luxurious lifestyle away from town and administration troubles, and secondly having his own problems with stubbortnly marrying [[Lavinia Veiongo Fotu]], was of no help. He only created for Sāteki the new noble title of [[:Category:Veikune|Veikune]] in 1903. Slowly but surely Sāteki forced, probably unwillingly, the kingdom from debts into almost bankruptcy, and there were more than serious talks about British annexation. Finally in December 1904 the British high commissioner of the Western Pacific, sir [[Everard im Thurn]] came to Tonga to make clean ship and to deport king and prime minister if needed.
And the end poor Sāteki and his son Fotu (minister of finance) were deported to Fiji, but king [[Siaosi Tupou II]] was allowed to remain but had to select new ministers.
*I.C. Campbell; Island kingdom; Canterbury press, 2001 {{Foki||Siosāteki Tonga Veikune}}

page.title: Siaosi Fatafehi Toutaitokotaha/en
page.text:
When the British high commissioner sir [[Everard im Thurn]] came in December 1904 to Tonga to put order in the mess, king [[Siaosi Tupou II]] had quickly to nominate new ministers. It is not quite clear how long Siaosi Tuʻipelehake, the father of the king, was actually prime minister. Perhaps a few days until [[Sione Tupou Mateialona]] was found. But still it is tradition to have his name mentioned in the official lists. But he then did become the treasurer.
In any case, in January 1905 Tonga became a British protectorate, with the government essentially regulated by the resident British consul, [[Hamilton Hunter]]. Tonga was lucky that the British did not straightout annex it. But they did not want to have also the responsibility of the care of the population on their shoulders.
Fatafehi's paternal grandmother [[Tupou Veiongo]], was also the mother of the last [[:Category:Tuʻi Tonga|Tuʻi Tonga]], [[Sanualio Laufilitonga]]. The latter wanted on his death in 1865 all prerogatives of his high office going to Fatafehi, which would make him, traditionally seen the most important man of the land. But Fatafehi did not want to antagonise his maternal grandfather king [[Siaosi Tupou I]] and relinquished to him most of the honour. Still he kept enough to make the [[:Category:Tuʻipelehake|Tuʻipelehake]] the second most important chiefly title of the country. He kept his own [[kava]] ritual (in the Tuʻi Tonga form) and was also known as [[Tuʻifaleua]] and [[ʻEikihāʻele]].
It is not quite clear whether all this, said to have originated with [[Talafale]] long long ago, was indeed already rooted in myth, or the myths were made up at the occassion.
Since 1865 both he and Tupou I were to be addressed with the royal register (the language reserved for the Tuʻi Tonga).
*I.C. Campbell; Island kingdom; Canterbury press, 2001 *E. Wood-Ellem, Queen Sālote of Tonga, Auckland university press, 1999 {{Foki||Siaosi Fatafehi Toutaitokotaha}}

page.title: Sione Tupou Mateialona/en
page.text:
With the declaration of the British protectorate over Tonga Mateialona became the new prime ministers. Luckily he had a good collaboration with the British consul, [[Hamilton Hunter]].
In 1909 a cooperative trading society known as the [[Tonga maʻa Tonga Kautaha]] was established, mainly to sell [[copra]], which was a great success, because it gave much more profit to the Tongan participants than any dealing of them with foreign traders, who put most of the profits in their own pockets. Of course they did not like that and started courtcases, so that soon the ''kautaha'' had become a political issue. King Tupou was manoeuvred to one side, for the Tongans. The British to the other, to the bad guys. And Mateialona, still friend with them, therefore fell. He resigned in May 1912, supposedly retiring, although he may have remained on as caretaker until September that year. [[Tēvita Polutele Kaho]], the chief of police would succeed him.
Later he became governor of Haʻapai, in 1918, one of the first appointments by the new queen [[Sālote Tupou III].
Although Mateialona was a grandson of Tupou I, he had not really a chiefly rank, as his father [[ʻIsileli Tupou]] had been declared illegitimate by the great man, and his mother was no great name either. Yet, with the house of Tupou running thin at the time, he was still a possible candidate for succession to the throne. In 1921 Sālote rewarded his support towards her by elevating him to a noble with the title [[:Category:Tupoutoʻa|Tupoutoʻa]], making him essentially the crown prince.
*I.C. Campbell; Island kingdom; Canterbury press, 2001 {{Foki||Sione Tupou Mateialona}}

page.title: Tēvita Polutele Kaho/en
page.text:
Polutele Kaho, as he was commony known before he received the noble title, was made into the Chief of police at the declaration of the British protectorate, in January 1905. Not really to the wish of king [[Siaosi Tupou II]], as Polutele was one of his strongest critics. But the British did not leave him any choice.
However the [[Tonga maʻa Tonga Kautaha]] case brought the two closer together, such that in 1912 Kaho, by then just installed as the noble [[:Category:Tuʻivakanō|Tuʻivakanō]], and as such from then commonly known as T.P. Tuʻivakanō, took over the prime minister office from the discredited [[Sione Tupou Mateialona]]. His younger brother, [[Sioape Alo Kaho]] became the minister of police in 1919 for the next 20 years.
He remained in office until 1923 when he retired, and he died little more than one month after.
*I.C. Campbell; Island kingdom; Canterbury press, 2001 {{Foki||Tēvita Polutele Kaho}}

page.title: Sioape Alo Kaho
page.text:
{{Kāinga ofi |hokohoko= Kaho, SA |maama= tangata |tamai=[[Manase Kahomovailahi]] |faʻē=[[ʻAnaseini Tokilupe ʻEveʻevaʻitoafa Kaho]] |ʻaho fanauʻi=~1877 pe 1878 |ʻaho pekia=9 ʻEpeleli 1959 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|Lātūsokopeti|[[Tēvita Polutele Kaho]]|[[Siosiua Niutupuʻivaha Kaho‎‎]]||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| | | ||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Manase Kaho]]|[[Feʻiloakitau Kaho]]|Taeao||||||}} |ʻohoana2= [[Muimui Kaho (Afuhaʻamango)]] |fānau2= {{tokoua|ʻikai? kae ko kui ia ʻo [[Tuʻimala Kaho]]||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= ? |ʻaho1= (ʻikai) |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[ʻOfa Veikune (Kaho)|ʻOfa]]||||||||}} |}}*E. Wood-Ellem, Queen Sālote of Tonga, Auckland university press, 1999 Minisitā polisi 1919—1939, fofonga fale alea 1942-1947, 1951-1953
Ko e [[punake]] ia, naʻa ne fatu ʻa e ngaahi taʻanga tauʻolunga: ʻOtolose vaioleti (~1910), Hiva ʻo Takipō (tuongaʻane ʻo Muimui) (1911 pe 1918).

page.title: Viliami Tupoulahi Tungī Mailefihi/en
page.text: When [[Tēvita Polutele Kaho]] retired as prime minister in 1923, queen Sālote appointed made her husband into the post, to make sure that the government was with her and not against her. In any case, the collaboration of queen and premier was a blessing for Tonga, which slowly started to crawl up to a higher standard of living. {{Foki||Viliami Tupoulahi Tungī Mailefihi}}

page.title: Leafāʻitulangi
Tuputupu ʻo Pulotu
Filiaipulotu
Lavinia Veiongo Veikune (Fotofili)
Nalesoni Laifone ʻUnga
Uelingatoni Ngū Tupoumālohi
page.text:
[[File:Uelingatoni Ngū, 1884.jpg|thumb]] {{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=fale ʻalo |maama= tangata |tamai= [[Tēvita ʻUnga]] |faʻē= [[Fifita Vavaʻu]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= 3 ʻAokosi 1854 |ʻaho pekia= 11 Maʻasi 1885 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[ʻElisiva Fusipala Taukiʻonetuku]]||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| ||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Nalesoni Laifone ʻUnga]]||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= ʻikai |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Setone Hopoate Fuaʻatonga]]|+toko 10|||||||}} |}}*http://www.planet-tonga.com/tongatimes/Taimi3-02-2004/news10.shtml
Naʻe ʻikai mali ia, kā naʻe ʻi ai ʻa e fānau tu'utamaki 'e toko 11.
Ko e tangata musika, ko Uelingatoni, pea ʻoku tatau pehē ʻene hako, Hopoate. Naʻe fatu ia ʻi 1874 ʻa e taʻanga ʻo e ''Fasi ʻo e tuʻi ʻo e ʻOtu Tonga'', pea naʻe hoko ki he [[fasi fakafonua]] ʻo Tonga.

page.title: Vaisima Hopoate
page.category: Hiva fakatonga|Hopoate V
page.text:
{{Kāinga ofi| |maama= tangata |hokohoko=Hopoate V |tamai= [[Setone Hopoate Fuaʻatonga]] |faʻē= |ʻaho fanauʻi= 1903 |ʻaho pekia= 1973 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[ʻAnamalia Katoʻone Veiongo Kaho (Hopoate)]]||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= ? |fānau1= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |}}Faʻeleʻi ʻi [[Tatakamotonga]].
ʻOku ui ko e punake lahi taha ia. Naʻe fatu ia ʻa e fasi ʻo e ''Puatalefusi'' mo ''Hala Vuna'' mo e hā fua. * N. Tukuʻaho, M. Taumoefolau, E. Wood-Ellem, A. Kaeppler; Songs & poems of Queen Sālote; ISBN 978-982-213-008-9 [[Category:Hiva fakatonga|Hopoate V]]

page.title: Setone Hopoate Fuaʻatonga
Tuʻuakitau
Siaosi Tupou II/en
page.text:
The succession of Tāufaʻāhau to the throne is a story on itself. He succeeded [[Siaosi Tupou I|Tāufaʻāhau Siaosi Tupou I]], who was his greatgrandfather, since the latter had outlived his children and grandchildren when he died about 96 years old. He had forcefully married with the highest ranking woman of the land, [[Sālote Lupepauʻu]] in 1834 and had without much ado all previous wives and their children declared illegitimate (as good Christians are supposed to have only one wife).
But he had no luck. The first son [[Tuʻuakitau]] died in 1842, only 3 years old. His pet and hope for the future, [[Vuna Takitakimālohi|Vuna]], followed the road to [[Pulotu]] or heavens in 1862. None had yet married. Only then Tāufaʻāhau looked at his other, illegitimate, sons. One of them [[ʻIsileli Tupou]] disappeared at sea. That then left only [[Tēvita ʻUnga]]. He died in 1875, but at least left 2 sons behind. Unfortunately the first, [[Uelingatoni Ngū Tupoumālohi]] died in 1885 and the second, [[Nalesoni Laifone ʻUnga]] in 1889. In despair Tāufaʻāhau then, in 1885, nominated [[Viliami Tungī Halatuituia]] to take over in case ʻUnga's line would fail completely.
But it never came that far. In fact Tēvita ʻUnga had had a daughter too [[ʻElisiva Fusipala Taukiʻonetuku]] (also died in 1889, a few months after her last brother), who had been married with [[Siaosi Fatafehi Toutaitokotaha]] a son of [[Sālote Mafileʻo Pilolevu (Tupou)]], who had been Tāufaʻāhau I's oldest daughter. Crooked as it seemed, but according to the letter of the constitution, their son, Tāufaʻāhau (Siaosi II) was considered the next in line. In fact it was old Tāufaʻāhau himself who announced in his will of 24 November 1889: ''Since Fusi is dead, who should have succeeded Laifone, then Tāufaʻāhau should inherit.''
Possibly with this wish he tried to bypass all envying chiefs, convinced as he was that they would tear apart the country anyway after his death.
*N. Tukuʻaho, M. Taumoefolau, E. Wood-Ellem, A. Kaeppler; Songs & poems of Queen Sālote; ISBN 978-982-213-008-9 *E. Wood-Ellem; Queen Sālote, the story of an era {{Foki||Siaosi Tupou II}}

Burley; Sacred child and sacred place; Polynesian paradox, USP 2005; ISBN 982-02-0371-6 Naʻe haʻu ia mei [[Lakeba]] ʻi [[Fisi]], ko ia ai ko e ʻuluaki [[:category:Tuʻilakepa|Tuʻilakepa]] ia. Naʻa ne telio ʻi he [[ʻotu langi|langi]] ʻo Muʻa. Na-moala ko e langi ia ʻo Tapuʻosi.

page.title: Lelenoa
Paleinangalu
Fehokomoelangiʻifisi
Vaea/en
Tongotea/en
page.text: Tongotea was the first [[moheofo]], the principal wife of the [[:Category:Tuʻi Tonga|Tuʻi Tonga]] provided by him from the [[:Category:Tuʻi Kanokupolu|Tuʻi Kanokupolu]] dynasty, and therefore the mother of the next Tuʻi Tonga. The role of the [[:Category:Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua|Tuʻi Haʻatakalaua]] to provide wives ([[māʻitaki]]) was superseded. {{Foki||Tongotea}}

page.text:
{{Houʻeiki|fakanofo= Tamahā |ʻaho fakanofo= ~1750 |ʻaho fakamālōlō= |ki muʻa= [[Simuoko]] |hoko= [[Lātūfuipeka]] |}}

Burley; Sacred child and sacred place; Polynesian paradox, USP 2005; ISBN 982-02-0371-6 Ko e tamahā naʻe ʻikai hā totonu ʻe [[Sālote Tupou III]]. Ko e tuongaʻane (!) ʻo Moʻungaolakepa (pe Moʻungaʻolakepa), ʻa ia ko Lātūnipuluʻiteafuana naʻe ui ia ko e ''tammaha'' ʻe he ʻeikivaka Semisi Kuki ʻi 1777.

Lātūnipuluʻiteafua

{{Houʻeiki|fakanofo= Tuʻilakepa |ʻaho fakanofo= ~1750 |ʻaho fakamālōlō= |ki muʻa= [[Fehokomoelangiʻifisi]] |hoko= [[ʻIloaʻilangikapu]] |}}
{{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=houʻeiki |maama= tangata |tamai= [[Fehokomoelangiʻifisi]] |faʻē= [[Sinaitakalaʻifanakavakilangi]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= ~1750 |ʻaho pekia= |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Moʻungaolakepa]]|Lāpuloufisi|||||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[Nanasipauʻu]] |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[ʻIloaʻilangikapu]]|[[Lātūfuipeka]]|||||||}} |ʻohoana2= [[Siumafuaʻuta]] |fānau2= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |}} Ko e tama ʻo ha [[:Category:Tuʻi Tonga Fefine|Tuʻi Tonga Fefine]], ko e [[sino ʻi ʻeiki|ʻeiki māʻolunga]] ʻaupito ʻa Lātūnipulu; naʻe pehē ʻe he ʻeikivaka [[Semisi Kuki]] ʻi 1773. Naʻe siʻisiʻi pē maʻana ʻa hono huafa ko Tuʻilakepa. *E. Bott; Tongan society at the time of Captain Cook’s visits: discussions with Her Majesty Queen Sālote, 1982. Memoir of The Polynesian Society '''44''', 16-17. Ko hai ko '''Takavaha''', ko e hoko ʻo e Tuʻilakepa, tatau mo ʻIloaʻilangikapu ?? *E.W. Gifford, Tongan Society, BPB museum bulletin 61, 1929

page.title: Fehokomoelangiʻifisi/en
page.text: There are several incertainties about Fehokomoelangiʻifisi. First was Paleinangalu his younger or older brother? The fact that Fehoko took his father's title may indicate he himself was the oldest. Secondly his father lived around ~1650, his son around ~1750. Either Fehoko got very old, or the genealogy is corrupt somewhere, maybe there is a mixup with a grandson of the same name. Since Fehoko lived in [[Nukulau]] in [[Fisi|Fiji]], this may be. {{Foki||Fehokomoelangiʻifisi}}

page.title: Tupou Veiongo
Halaevalu (TK)
ʻIsileli Tupou
Tupou Moheofo
page.text:
[[File:Tubou, descendant of Tui Tonga dynasty (1898).jpg|thumb|200px]] {{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=houʻeiki |maama= fefine |tamai= [[ʻIsileli Tupou]] |faʻē= [[Lavinia Veiongo (māhanga)|Lavinia Veiongo]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= ~1860 |ʻaho pekia=24 Nōvema 1918 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Sione Tupou Mateialona]]||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| ||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Luseane Angaʻaefonu ʻInoke]]|Kalauta|||||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[Siaosi Tupou II]] |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Viliami Vīlai Vakalotu Tupou]]||||||||}} |ʻohoana2= [[Siale ʻAtaongo]] |fānau2= {{tokoua|Sālote Fisi|[[Vāhoi]]|||||||}} |}}*E. Wood-Ellem, Queen Sālote of Tonga, Auckland university press, 1999
Ko e maka fakamanatu ʻi he tafaʻaki ʻo e [[ʻotu langi|Paepae ʻo Teleʻa]] ʻi [[Lapaha]] ʻoku ne pehē: ::Ko e ʻuluaki mēmipa ʻeni mei he fale ʻo [[:Category:Haʻa Moheofo|haʻa moheofó]] kuo kau ki he [[Siasi Māmonga|Siasi ʻo Sīsū Kalaisi ʻo e kau māʻoniʻoni he ngaahi ʻaho ki mui ní]] pea ko e fuofua papitaiso foki ia ʻi Tongatapu hili e tūʻuta mai ʻa e ongo faifekau mei [[:Category:Vavaʻu|Vavaʻu]], ko William F Winn mo George W Seeley, 17 ʻo Maʻasi 1911. Naʻe fakahoko e ʻouaú ni ʻe misi uini he ʻaho 15 ʻo Siulai 1911, ʻi he matātahi Fongoloá<ref>[sic], ko Fangaloa ko hono hingoa</ref>, feʻunga mo e tuʻuʻanga ʻo e falemahaki he ʻaho ko iá. Naʻe hāʻele ki ai ʻa kingi [[Siaosi Tupou II]], ke ʻafio tonu ki he ouau ʻo e papitaisó. ''Naʻe tatala e pulonga e maká ni e kuini [[Halaevalu Mataʻaho ʻAhomeʻe|Halaevalu Mataʻaho]] ʻi he ʻaho 22 ʻo Sune 2007 ʻi he manatu ʻofa ki siʻi Tupou Moheofó ʻa ia ne pekia he 1918.'' <references/>

page.title: ʻIlaisaane Tupouʻāhau
Siosiana Tongovua Tae Manusā
ʻAnaseini Takipō Afuhaʻamango
page.text:
{{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=fale ʻalo |maama= fefine |tamai= [[Tēvita Ula Afuhaʻamango]] |faʻē= [[Siosiana Tongovua Tae Manusā]] |ʻaho fanauʻi= 1 Maʻasi 1893 |ʻaho pekia=26 Nōvema 1918 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Vika Kaufusi Fulivai (Afuhaʻamango)]]|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua| ||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Muimui Kaho (Afuhaʻamango)]]||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[Siaosi Tupou II]] |ʻaho1=11 Nōvema 1909 |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[ʻOnelua]]|[[ʻElisiva Fusipala Taukiʻonetuku (Tupou)]]|||||||}} |}} Naʻe ui ko Takipō ia, ko e ʻuhinga ʻene fāʻeleʻi taimi nounou pē ʻosi ʻa e hala ʻo [[Siaosi Tupou I]].
==Hiva ʻo Takipō== Fatu ʻe [[Sioape Alo Kaho]] ~1911 maʻa ʻene ʻohoana, ko [[Muimui Kaho (Afuhaʻamango)]] ke ne ʻoatu ia ki hono tuongaʻane.
[[Kakala]] ʻo Tonga te u luva atu [[huni|kulukona]], [[langakali]], [[heilala]] ngangatu [[motelolo]] mo e pua te u toe ʻoatu ko siʻo kakala ʻo ka ke folau.
ʻIkai ʻaupito te u ʻilo ʻe au ʻoku langa pea uhu ʻa e ʻofa manatu vaivai ʻa e sino mo e ʻatamai ko mate te ne lava ke toe tatali
Te u ʻofa atu, te u ʻofa pē te u ʻofa ke aʻu ki he mate ʻe lelei ʻeku mate ʻaku ʻi he [[lose]] he ʻeku moʻui mamahi pehē.
==Tataku== *E. Wood-Ellem; Queen Sālote of Tonga; Auckland university press 1999 *Langi tauʻolunga & hiva kakala; Nukuʻalofa 2000; ISBN 978-982-98007-1-8 [[category:Hiva fakatonga|Afuhaʻamango ʻAT]]

page.title: Hokohoko ki he Kalauni
page.link: Sālote Lupepauʻu Salamasina Purea Vahine Arii ʻo e Hau Tuita
Frederica Lupeʻuluiva Fatafehi ʻo Lapaha Tuita
ʻAngelika Lātūfuipeka Halaʻevalu Mataʻaho Napuaʻokalani Tukuʻaho
Siaosi Manumataongo ʻAlaivahamamaʻo ʻAhoʻeitu Konstantin Tukuʻaho
page.text:
Toʻo mei he konisitūtone ʻo Tonga (T.L. 1988)
===Ko e anga e hokohoko ki he Kalauni.=== 32. ʻOku maʻu ʻa e Kalauni mo e Nofoʻanga Faka-Tuʻi 'o e Puleʻanga ni ʻe he ʻEne ʻAfio ko Kingi [[Siaosi Tupou I]] pea ʻoku takapapau ni ʻe maʻu ʻe ia pea mo ia naʻe tupu ʻiate ia ʻa [[Tēvita ʻUnga]] pea mo ia naʻe tupu ai ʻa Uelingatoni Ngū mo kinautolu ʻe tupu ʻiate Ia ko ʻene fanau mali pea ka hala ia ʻo ʻikai ha hako tupu mali ʻo [[Uelingatoni Ngū Tupoumālohi|Uelingatoni Ngū]] ʻe hoko ʻo hangē ko e lao ʻo e hokohoko ni: Pea ko ʻeni ʻa e anga ʻo e hokohoko ʻe ngofua ke kau ʻi he hokohoko ni ʻa e fanau tupu mali pe pea ʻe hoko ki he tamasiʻi tangata mo e ngaahi ʻea ʻo hono sino pea ka hala ia ʻo ʻikai hano hako ʻe hoko ki hono ua ʻo e tamasiʻi tangata mo e ngaahi ʻea ʻo hono sino pea fai pehe kae ʻoua kuo ʻosi ʻa e fānau tangata pea ka ʻikai ha tamasiʻi tangata ʻe hoko ki he ʻuluaki tamasiʻi fefine mo e ngaahi ʻea ʻo hono sino pea ka hala ia ʻo 'ikai hano hako ʻe hoko ki hono ua ʻo e tamasiʻi fefine mo e ngaahi ʻea ʻo hono sino pea fai pehē kae ʻoua kuo ʻosi ʻa e fanau fefine. Pea ka ʻikai ha taha ʻiate kinautolu ʻo Tēvita ʻUnga ko e fanau mali hoko totonu ke hoko ki he Kalauni ʻo e Tuʻi ʻo Tonga ʻe hoko kia [[Viliami Tungī Halatuituia|Uiliami Tungī]] pe ko hono ngaahi ʻea totonu ʻa ia ʻoku tupu ʻi hono sino ko e fānau mali pea mo e ngaahi ʻea ʻoku tupu ʻiate kinautolu foki. Pea ka ʻikai ha ʻea totonu ʻe fakanofo ʻe he Tuʻi ʻa hono ʻea kapau ʻoku loto ki ai ʻa e Houʻeiki Nōpele (ka ʻoku ʻikai kau ai ʻa e kau fakafofonga ʻo e kakai) pea 'e fakahāhā ko e ʻea ia ki he Kalauni ʻi he kei lakoifie ʻa e Tuʻi. Pea ka faifai pea ʻikai ha ʻea mo e hoko totonu ki he Kalauni ha taha kuo fakahāhā ʻo hangē ko e tuʻutuʻuni ni ʻe fakataha leva ʻe he Palemia pea ka mamaʻo ia ʻe ʻi he Kapineti (ko e kau Minisita) ʻa e Houʻeiki Nōpele ʻo e Fale Alea (pea ʻe ʻikai kau ai ʻa e kau fakafofonga ʻo e kakai) pea ka fakataha ʻe fili ʻe he houʻeiki Nopele ʻo e Fale Alea ʻaki ʻa e paloti ha taha ʻo e Houʻeiki ʻa ia ʻoku nau loto ki ai ke hoko ko e Tuʻi pea ʻe hoko ia ko e kamata'anga ʻo e Haʻa Tuʻi foʻou pea ʻe maʻu ʻe hono ngaahi ʻea ʻoku tupu ʻiate ia ʻi hono sino ko e fānau mali ʻa e Kalauni ʻo hangē ko e lao ni pea ka faifai pea ʻikai ha hoko ʻiate kinautolu ʻo hangē ko e lao ni ʻe toe fakataha ʻe he Palemia pea ka mamaʻo ia ʻe ʻi he Kapineti mo e Houʻeiki Nōpele ʻo e Fale Alea ʻo hangē ko e tuʻutuʻuni ni pea te nau toe fili ha taha ke hoko ki he Kalauni ko e kamataʻanga ʻo e Haʻa Tuʻi foʻou pea ʻe fai pehē ai pe ʻo hangē ko e lao ni ʻo lauikuonga.
===ʻE ʻikai ngofua ki ha taha ʻa ia ʻe hoko ko e ʻEa ki he Kalauni he mali mo ha taha ʻikai finangalo ki ai ʻa e Tuʻi.=== 33. (1) ʻE ʻikai siʻi ngofua ki ha taha ʻo e famili ʻo e Tuʻi ha taha ʻe faifai pea ngali hoko ki he Kalauni ke mali mo ha taha ʻoku ʻikai loto ki ai ʻa e Tuʻi. Pea ka fai ha mali pehē ʻe ʻikai lau ko e mali fakalao<ref>kupu 12/69 mo e lao 4 ʻo e 1970 kau kia [[Mele Siuʻilikutapu Kalaniuvalu (Tukuʻaho)]] mo kupu 133/80 mo e lao 7 ʻo e 1980 kau kia [[Fatafehi ʻAlaivahamamaʻo Tukuʻaho]]</ref> ia pea ʻe ngofua ki he Tuʻi ke liliu ʻa e totonu ʻo e tokotaha ko ia ke ʻoua ʻaupito naʻa hoko ia ki he Kalauni ʻo Tonga<ref>vakai: lao fakalahi ʻo e konisitūtone</ref> pe ko hono hako. Pea ka fai ia ʻe maʻu ia ʻe ia ʻoku hoko ki he tokotaha ko ia pea lau ko e ʻea ia pea ko e talangataʻa ʻe lau ia ʻo hangē kuo mate. (2) Ko e kupuʻi lea ko ''ha taha ʻe faifai pea ngali hoko ki he kalauni'' ʻi he kupusiʻi fakaʻosi kimuʻa angé, kuo pau ke fakaʻuhingaʻi ia ke fakakauʻi ai ʻa kinautolu kotoa pe kuo fanauʻi ʻi he mali fakalao pea ʻoku fehokotaki taʻataʻa mo e Tuʻi ʻi he hohoko ʻo e hako tukufakaholo, pe hako ofi tahá ka he ʻikai ke lahi hake ʻi he toko uofolu hono mamaʻo ʻi he fakahokohoko mei he Tuʻi.
==Hokohoko kahaʻu== Ko e tuʻi lolotonga: ʻAhoʻeitu ʻUnuakiʻotonga Tukuʻaho ([[Tupou VI]]) #[[Siaosi Manumataongo ʻAlaivahamamaʻo ʻAhoʻeitu Konstantin Tukuʻaho]] (ʻUlukālala) #[[Viliami ʻUnuaki-ʻo-Tonga Mumui Lalaka-mo-e-ʻEiki Tukuʻaho]] (Ata) #[[ʻAngelika Lātūfuipeka Halaʻevalu Mataʻaho Napuaʻokalani Tukuʻaho]] #[[Sālote Mafileʻo Pilolevu Tuita (Tukuʻaho)]] #[[Sālote Lupepauʻu Salamasina Purea Vahine Arii ʻo e Hau Tuita]] #[[ʻAnaseini Tupouveihola ʻIkaleti-olo-ʻi-Fangatapu Phaedra Fusituʻa]] #[[Titilupe Fanetupouvavaʻu Tuita]] #[[Frederica Lupeʻuluiva Fatafehi ʻo Lapaha Tuita]] #[[Lupeolo Halaevalu Moheofo Tuita]]
{{English|more}} <references/> [[category:Fakapuleʻanga]]

page.title: Hokohoko ki he Kalauni/en
page.link: Sālote Lupepauʻu Salamasina Purea Vahine Arii ʻo e Hau Tuita
Frederica Lupeʻuluiva Fatafehi ʻo Lapaha Tuita
ʻAngelika Lātūfuipeka Halaʻevalu Mataʻaho Napuaʻokalani Tukuʻaho
Siaosi Manumataongo ʻAlaivahamamaʻo ʻAhoʻeitu Konstantin Tukuʻaho
page.text:
Taken from the constitution of Tonga
===32 Succession to the Throne=== The right and title of King [[Siaosi Tupou I|George Tupou I]] to the Crown and the Throne of this Kingdom were confirmed by the Constitution of 1875 and it was further declared in the said Constitution that the succession to the Crown and Throne should devolve upon [[Tēvita ʻUnga|David Uga]] and then upon [[Uelingatoni Ngū Tupoumālohi|Wellington Gu]] and then upon them begotten by him in marriage and if at any time there be no heirs of Wellington Gu the Crown and Throne shall descend in accordance with the following law of succession: It shall be lawful only for those born in marriage to succeed. The succession shall be to the eldest male child and the heirs of his body but if he should have no children to the second male child and the heirs of his body and so on until all the male line shall be ended. Should there be no male child the eldest female child shall succeed and the heirs of her body and if she should have no children it shall descend to the second female child and the heirs of her body until the female line is ended. And if there shall be none of this line of David Uga lawful descendants by marriage to succeed to the Crown of Tonga it shall descend to [[Viliami Tungī Halatuituia|William Tugi]] and his lawful heirs begotten by him in marriage and to their heirs begotten by them. And if there should be no lawful heir the King shall appoint his heir if the House of Nobles consent to it (the representatives of the people having no voice in the matter) and he shall be publicly declared heir to the Crown during the King's life. Should there be no heir to the Crown or successor who has been so publicly proclaimed the Prime Minister or in his absence the Cabinet ministers shall convoke the nobles of the Legislative Assembly (the representatives of the people having no voice in the matter) and when they meet the House of Nobles shall choose by ballot some one of the chiefs whom they wish to succeed as King. And he shall succeed as the first of a new dynasty and he and the heirs of his body born in marriage shall possess the Crown according to law. And in the event of there being none to succeed according to this law the Prime Minister or in his absence the Cabinet ministers shall again convoke the nobles of the Legislative Assembly in accordance with this law and they shall choose one to succeed to the Throne as the first of a new dynasty and so on according to this law for ever.
===33 Heir Apparent may not choose consort=== #It shall not be lawful for any member of the Royal Family who is likely to succeed to the throne to marry any person without the consent of the King. And if any person should thus marry the marriage shall not be considered legal and it shall be lawful for the King to cancel the right of such person and his heirs to succeed to the Crown of Tonga. And the next person in succession to him who so marries shall be declared the heir and the offender shall be regarded as dead. #The expression ''any member of the Royal Family who is likely to succeed to the throne'' in the last preceding sub-clause shall be construed to include all persons born in lawful marriage and related by descent either lineally or collaterally to the King but not more than twenty times removed from the King. (Inserted by Act 3 of 1971.)
==Also see== [[Siaosi Tupou II/en]]
==Future succession line== Current king: ʻAhoʻeitu ʻUnuakiʻotonga Tukuʻaho ([[Tupou VI]]) #[[Siaosi Manumataongo ʻAlaivahamamaʻo ʻAhoʻeitu Konstantin Tukuʻaho]] (ʻUlukālala) #[[Viliami ʻUnuaki-ʻo-Tonga Mumui Lalaka-mo-e-ʻEiki Tukuʻaho]] (Ata) #[[ʻAngelika Lātūfuipeka Halaʻevalu Mataʻaho Napuaʻokalani Tukuʻaho]] #[[Sālote Mafileʻo Pilolevu Tuita (Tukuʻaho)]] #[[Sālote Lupepauʻu Salamasina Purea Vahine Arii ʻo e Hau Tuita]] #[[ʻAnaseini Tupouveihola ʻIkaleti-olo-ʻi-Fangatapu Phaedra Fusituʻa]] #[[Titilupe Fanetupouvavaʻu Tuita]] #[[Frederica Lupeʻuluiva Fatafehi ʻo Lapaha Tuita]] #[[Lupeolo Halaevalu Moheofo Tuita]] {{Foki||Hokohoko ki he Kalauni}}

page.title: Tēvita Ula Afuhaʻamango
page.text:
{{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=houʻeiki |maama= tangata |tamai=Setaleki Afuha'amango |faʻē=Kasanita Vea Tokelau |ʻaho fanauʻi=~1850 |ʻaho pekia=5 Fēpueli 1925 |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[Siosiana Tongovua Tae Manusā]] |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Vika Kaufusi Fulivai (Afuhaʻamango)|Vika Kaufusi]]|[[ʻAnaseini Takipō Afuhaʻamango|ʻAnaseini Takipō]]|[[Muimui Kaho (Afuhaʻamango)|Muimui]]||||||}} |}}*E. Hingoa kakato: Tevita 'Ula Puluhifi o'e Tau Afuha'amango.
Matāpule mei [[:category:Vavaʻu|Vavaʻu]] ia, kae naʻe ʻikai te ne maʻu ʻa e huafa [[:category:nōpele|nōpele]]. Naʻe feinga ʻe he tuʻi (ʻosi ʻene taʻane mo Takipō) ke maʻu ha tofiʻa moʻona ʻi 1910, kā naʻe tapu ia ʻe he [[falealea]].

page.title: Siosateki Faletau
page.text:

page.title: Feʻiloakitau Kaho
Manase Kahomovailahi
page.text: {{Kāinga ofi |faʻahinga=houʻeiki |maama= tangata |tamai= [[Poʻoi Niutupuʻivaha]] |faʻē= Siulolovao Sisi Toutaitokotaha |ʻaho fanauʻi= ~1850 |ʻaho pekia= |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|[[Mekemeke]]||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[ʻAnaseini Tokilupe ʻEveʻevaʻitoafa Kaho]] |fānau1= {{tokoua|Lātūsokopeti|[[Tēvita Polutele Kaho|Tēvita Polutele]]|[[Siosiua Niutupuʻivaha Kaho‎‎|Siosiua Niutupuʻivaha]]|[[Sioape Alo Kaho|Sioape Alo]]|[[Manase Kaho|Manase]]|[[Feʻiloakitau Kaho|Feʻiloakitau]]|Taeao|||}} |}}*http://epress.anu.edu.au/austronesians/origins/mobile_devices/ch12s02.html Naʻe fakanofo ʻa e ʻeiki ʻo Manase, ko Poʻoi, mo e hingoa [[:Category:Tuita|Tuita]], kae ʻosi ʻene pekia naʻe foki ʻa e hingoá ni ki he foha ʻo e taʻokete ʻo Poʻoi, ko [[Makahokovalu]], ʻa ia naʻe ʻikai maʻu ʻa e huafa ni ʻe Manase. Monū, ko e tuongaʻane ʻo ʻAna, ko [[Manuʻatua Tuʻivakanō]], ko e ʻeiki [[:Category:Tuʻivakanō|Tuʻivakanō]], naʻe ʻikai haʻane hako. ʻA ia ʻi he kahaʻu naʻe fakanofo ʻa Tēvita Polutele mo e huafa ē.

page.title: ʻInitia/en
page.text: India, officially the Republic of India (Bhārata Gaṇarājya), is a country in South Asia. It is the seventh-largest country by geographical area, the second most populous country, and the most populous liberal democracy in the world. India has a coastline of over seven thousand kilometres, bounded by the Indian Ocean on the south, the Arabian Sea on the west, and the Bay of Bengal on the east. India borders Pakistan to the west;China, Nepal and Bhutan to the north-east; and Bangladesh and Myanmar to the east. In the Indian Ocean, India is in the vicinity of Sri Lanka, Maldives and Indonesia. {{Foki||ʻInitia}}

page.title: Sisilia Tupou-mo-Lakepa Kalaniuvalu (Tuʻitavake)
page.text:
{{Kāinga ofi|faʻahinga=houʻeiki |hokohoko=Tuʻitavake ST |maama= fefine |tamai= [[Tuʻitavake]] |faʻē= Melenaite |ʻaho fanauʻi= ~1910 |ʻaho pekia= |taʻokete-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |taʻokete-lau= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |tehina-tokoua= {{tokoua|||||||||}} |ʻohoana1= [[Semisi Fonua Kalaniuvalu]] |ʻaho1= 8-10 Sune 1932 |fānau1= {{tokoua|[[Lavinia Veiongo ʻAhomeʻe (Kalaniuvalu)|Lavinia Veiongo]]|[[Siosiua Ngalumoetutulu Kalaniuvalu|Siosiua Ngalumoetutulu]]|ʻAmelia Adi Uvu|Sione Ueʻikaetau|Siosaia Afuitangimana|Tangi mei muli ʻa Tupoutoʻa|?|?|}} |}}* E. Wood-Ellem, Queen Sālote of Tonga, Auckland university press, 1999
==Hiva ʻo Silia Kalaniuvalu== Hiva kakala fatu ʻe [[Tēvita Kavaefiafi]] ʻi ~1930 maʻa Semisi ki hono ʻofa. Ta koā ni ne u mohe ʻo misi ʻoku ou ʻi he moʻunga fekita mo e ʻofa ki moana ʻa leva ʻo tāfuʻua tala ʻe he konisēnisi ava e matapā koula fakaʻamunoa ʻa e loto ke u sei he fisi ʻo e [[vunga]].
ʻEte siofia e ʻatā manumaʻa ʻena ʻoku puna ʻo vaʻinga he vao [[fā|hingano]] pea foki mai ʻo tuʻula ʻi he [[kahoa kakala|veʻeveʻe faifio]] luva mei he [[futu|Futu-ko-Vuna]] kae ʻilo ʻoku mānoa ʻa e [[Mapa-ko-Mataʻiʻulua]].
Taumaiā ke u puna atu ke mamaʻo toʻo hake pea ʻomi ʻa [[Niuafoʻou|Vailahimoekaho]] ʻo lī atu ki [[ʻOnemalama]] mo e fuʻu fā ʻi he ano ko fakamoʻoni e loto kuo fonu he ʻofa manako.
==Tataku== *Langi tauʻolunga & hiva kakala; Nukuʻalofa 2000; ISBN 978-982-98007-1-8 [[category:Hiva fakatonga|Kalaniuvalu STL]]

page.title: Kalolaine Tongilava
Malinoa
page.category: Tongatapu & takatakai
Hisitōlia ʻo Tonga
page.text:
[[Image:Malinoa.jpg|thumb|left|400px|Ko e motu ʻo Malinoa mei he tokelau, ʻoku kei tuʻu ʻa e falemaama ʻi 2006]] [[Image:Malinoa (1).gif|right|350px|thumb|Malinoa (motu)]] [[Image:Tumulus (1).jpg|thumb|left|300px|Ko e faʻitoka ʻo e tokoono, pe ha sia fakanatula ?]] Ko '''Malinoa''' ko e kiʻi motu ia ʻi he tokelau ʻo e taulanga [[Nukuʻalofa]].
ʻOku ui ko e motu malaʻia, ko e uhi ʻi 1 Fēpueli 1887, [[:Category:Tuʻuhetoka|Tuʻuhetoka]], ko e minisitā polisi ʻi he taimi ko ia, naʻe tāmateʻi fakalao ʻe ia ʻa e toko ono ko Tōpui, ʻAisea Kaumoto, Lavuso, Naisa, Lātū mo Fehoko. ʻI he fekau ia ʻo [[Siaosi Tupou I]], koeʻuhi naʻa nau feinga tāmateʻi ʻa [[Shirley Waldemar Baker]].
Tatau mo e ngaahi motu kehekehe, he onopooni ʻoku keina ia ʻe he ngaahi peau ʻo e tahi, pea ʻoku tuai kae pau ʻene fakasiʻisiʻi ange. Ko e falemaama naʻe tuʻu lōloa mei he matātahi tokelau ʻi he teautaʻu hono 20, naʻe tō ʻi he tahi ʻi 2010 pe ofi ki ai.
{{feituʻu Tonga|21°036|175°129}} {{English|more}} [[Category:Tongatapu & takatakai]] [[Category:Hisitōlia ʻo Tonga]]

page.title: Malinoa/en
page.text:
Little Malinoa is the northern most island in the series of small islands leading to the harbour of Nukuʻalofa and as such a navigational beacon for those coming from Haʻapai and Vavaʻu heading for Tongatapu.
On 12 January 1887, 5 young Tongans, from the repressed [[Muʻa parliament]] Topui first cousin of Tungi and Lavuso also a cousin both from the old parliament and few others tried to murder the premier, [[Shirley Waldemar Baker]]. Shirley himself escaped unharmed but his son and daughter were severily wounded. King [[Siaosi Tupou I]] became very angry when he heard about it and considered it an act of rebellion. He ordered the chiefs to deliver the criminals directly to him, and when his old political enemies did not act quickly enough, he sent the policeforce. Soon it all degenerated into a battle between pro and anti- Tupou factions, rekindling the fire of the Muʻa parliament, which had barely been extinguished.
Nevertheless at the end the those who were responsible were arrested without trial, on 31 January 10 of them were sentenced to death. The same evening Baker, assisted by the minister of police, Tuʻuhetoka, went to the palace to beg Tupou to commute the sentences. The king did not want to listen, and the others left in the hope to try the next day again. But shortly after midnight the king ordered Tuʻuhetoka to take 6 of the condemned, Tōpui, ʻAisea Kaumoto, Lavuso, Naisa, Lātū and Fehoko to Malinoa to execute them there. And so they died there from a firing squad. Sand was heaped up on their graves, and this gravehill is said to still exist nowadays (see picture, although this is the only hill on Malinoa, it is not sure it is the right spot).
After the firing prince [[Nalesoni Laifone ʻUnga|Laifone]] took the coconuts from the island, saying it would be the last ones as the island would be accursed forever.
When king Tupou was briefed over the happenings, he ordered Tuʻuhetoka to act with the remaining 4 prisoners on the deathroll in the same way, namely Palu, Tavake, Fekau and Tuʻitavake. But then Baker intervened, and at the end they were never shot but banished instead.
*N. Rutherford, Shirley Baker and the king of Tonga, Wellington 1971/1995 {{Foki||Malinoa}}
